dcterms:title: Increased frequency of clonal hematopoiesis of indeterminate potential in Bloom syndrome probands and carriers
dcterms:abstract: Bloom syndrome (BSyn, OMIM #210900) is a rare autosomal recessive disorder characterized by growth restriction, sun sensitivity, insulin resistance, mild immune deficiency, and increased risk of early-onset malignancy. BSyn cases are caused by homozygous or compound heterozygous pathogenic variants (PV) in BLM, with over 547 different PV identified in ClinVar. The Bloom Syndrome Registry (BSR) recently reported that 53% of participants had developed cancer, with hematologic malignancies being the most common cancer risk. While several studies have shown no association of carriers having increased risk, recent studies have identified increased risk of cancers in BLM PV carriers such as colorectal cancer, breast cancer and mesothelioma.

obi:OBI_0000299.dcterms:description: Exome sequencing data from 29 peripheral blood DNA samples from BSR, including ten BSyn probands and their biological parents

obi:BFO_0000050.dcterms:description: The paper discusses clonal hematopoiesis of indeterminate potential (CHIP) as a specific form of hematopoiesis characterized by somatic mutations in leukemia-related genes.

obi:RO_0002304.dcterms:description: The study shows that germline variants in DNA repair genes are associated with increased prevalence of clonal hematopoiesis.

obi:BFO_0000066.dcterms:description: The paper identifies somatic mutations in peripheral blood leukocytes with variant allele frequencies >0.02 as characteristic of CHIP.

obi:OBI_0000299.dcterms:title: Bloom syndrome
obi:OBI_0000299.dcterms:description: Characterized by growth restriction, sun sensitivity, insulin resistance, mild immune deficiency, and increased risk of early-onset malignancy. 53% of participants developed cancer, with hematologic malignancies being the most common cancer risk. Study found that both Bloom syndrome patients and BLM carriers exhibited increased frequency of clonal hematopoiesis compared to controls.

obi:OBI_0000299.dcterms:title: leukemia
obi:OBI_0000299.dcterms:description: CHIP is associated with an annual increased risk of leukemia ranging from 0.5% to 1.0%. Multiple cases of acute lymphoblastic leukemia and acute myeloid leukemia were observed in Bloom syndrome patients post-collection.

obi:OBI_0000299.dcterms:title: hematologic cancer
obi:OBI_0000299.dcterms:description: Most common cancer risk in Bloom syndrome patients. Study identified increased frequency of low frequency, putatively somatic variants in CHIP genes in Bloom syndrome probands and BLM carriers, suggesting potential mechanism for increased hematologic cancer risk.

obi:OBI_0000299.dcterms:title: colorectal cancer
obi:OBI_0000299.dcterms:description: Recent studies have identified increased risk of colorectal cancer in BLM pathogenic variant carriers.

obi:OBI_0000299.dcterms:title: breast cancer
obi:OBI_0000299.dcterms:description: Recent studies have identified increased risk of breast cancer in BLM pathogenic variant carriers.

obi:OBI_0000299.dcterms:title: DNA
obi:OBI_0000299.dcterms:description: DNA repair and telomere maintenance genes are associated with increased prevalence of clonal hematopoiesis. BLM pathogenic variants in DNA affect genomic integrity and are linked to increased somatic mutation rates and cancer risk.

obi:OBI_0000299.dcterms:title: insulin
obi:OBI_0000299.dcterms:description: Insulin resistance is one of the characteristics of Bloom syndrome, alongside growth restriction and sun sensitivity.

obi:OBI_0000299.dcterms:title: nucleic acids
obi:OBI_0000299.dcterms:description: Variants in nucleic acids were analyzed through exome sequencing, revealing increased frequency of clonal hematopoiesis in Bloom syndrome probands and carriers.
